section.title: Beginning Mi'gmaq
section.note: Welcome to Learn Mi'gmaq Online! In this first section, you will learn the basics of the language. We'll start by learning the sounds of the language. After working on pronunciation and listening, you will learn basic introductions. Next, we will look at how to talk about people. This will help you pick up on some grammatical concepts, like how to talk about different kinds of groups of people, how to count, and how to build basic sentences. This section also includes some tips on how to study Mi'gmaq.

It's important to practice along as you hear dialogs. Learning how to speak and understand Mi'gmaq is the primary goal of this website. Although many speakers feel nervous about speaking because everyone makes mistakes as they are learning, the best way to improve your pronunciation is just to practice. Every time you hear a sentence, you should repeat it out loud until you have mastered the rhythm and sounds of the words.

unit.title: Introductions, Lang-learning, Family, Speaking the Language
unit.note: In this unit, you will learn how to introduce yourself, how to talk about your family, and how to name basic objects around you. The vocabulary in this unit will give us basic building blocks for building more complex sentences later. As always, you should practice speaking along with the recordings in each lesson.

lesson.title: Introductions
lesson.note: This lesson will teach you the basics of how to describe yourself and your relations. You will learn how to describe yourself, your family, your home, and your work to others. These are important skills to learn at the beginning, because once you have mastered these basics, you will be able to begin conversations and introduce yourself to other Mi'gmaq speakers when you meet them.
lesson.designnote: This lesson starts learners out in the language with the main ways they can describe themselves and their relations: their name, their parents, and where they come from, where they live, and where they work. Being about to name their parents (and where they come from) right off is a particularly important part of self-introduction for learners, since this allows older speakers from their community to place them among the people they know.

line.english: My father is also from Listuguj.

lesson.title: Useful phrases for language learning IN the language
lesson.note: Here are some useful phrases to help you ask questions in the language to help you learn more. Practice these phrases so that you can speak the language as much as possible.
When you learn a new language, you want to stay speaking in the language as much as possible: the more your mind goes back to English, the slower you will learn.

One trick to keep the conversation in Mig'maq (even if you're not following everything) is to learn how to ask your major questions about the language in the language. Here we give the first of a series of phrases that you can use to help stay in the game, no matter what.
lesson.designnote: This particular lesson is offered right from the start, because it is most effective for learners to learn the language THROUGH the language. By giving them the crucial phrases for this early on, we aim to encourage doing this as much as possible from the getgo, instead of dropping back to English. Learners of course naturally drop back to English, but so do speakers, since it is the language they have used with non-speakers for years. A successful learner has to overcome not only their own lifelong habits of using English, but also has to find polite, respectful ways of turning the conversation from English back to Mi'gmaq wherever reasonably possible. These phrases are one of the key ways they can do this.

line.english: Please speak to me in Native.
Would you be so kind as to talk to me in Native?
Tell me in Native what you are doing.
Tell me in Native what I am doing.
Where would you use that word?
How would I use that word?
Please tell me something in Native.

lesson.designnote: The following four lines are the preferred replacements for the "blanks" lines.

line.english: I want to know how you say "I am hungry".
I want to ask you something. How do you say "pail"?
I want to ask you how you say "full moon".

lesson.title: Identifying people
lesson.note: In this lesson, you will learn to ask about and identify people around you. You will also be able to describe your family and answer basic questions about them.
In English, we ask 'What is that?' to ask someone to tell us what kind of animal we are looking at. But in Mi'gmaq, it is natural to ask "Who is this/that?"— exactly the same as for people.
This is one way you can learn new words without having to speak any English at all.
lesson.designnote: This lesson teaches the 'this' and 'that' words of Mi'gmaq, as well as the important question 'who?', and the important /X na Y/ pattern, which acts as an effective equivalent to English 'X is Y, X = Y'. It grounds this in an introduction to part of the four-way system of [older/younger brother/sister] vs. the English two-way system of [brother/sister]. It requires pictures---and would be even better if video---to see the near (ula) and far (ala), and which people the speakers are looking at.

line.english: No, this is my younger brother.
No, that is my younger sister.

lesson.title: Identifying things
lesson.note: Now we will learn how to ask and answer questions about household objects. These phrases are again very good for learning Mi'gmaq by speaking Mi'gmaq. With them, you can point to something (some thing) and learn the word for it without having to speak English.
lesson.designnote: This lesson introduces the fundamental 'what is this/that?' question so basic to learning a language THROUGH the language. It also reinforces the previously introduced /X na Y/ pattern as an effective equivalent to English 'X is Y, X = Y'. It requires pictures, better if video, to see the near (ula) and far (ala), and which people the speakers are looking at.

lesson.title: Identifying siblings overall
lesson.note: Listen carefully to the lines below. Use 'wen' for 'who?' when you're asking about one person. Use 'wenig' for 'who?' when you're asking about more than one person.
lesson.designnote: This lesson introduces plural 'who' (not found directly in English), and presents wijigumjig as an unexplained 'your siblings/brothers and sisters'. An expanded version of this lesson might have an answer using wijigumgig 'my, those who I'. This would at least introduce that basic 'I ___ them', 'you ___ them' pattern. Here however, drawing too much attention to this pattern might overload learners.

line.english: Who are your brothers and sisters?

lesson.title: Identifying siblings by relation
lesson.note: So far, you have learned the question taluisin?,' 'what is your name?', and the answer, teluisi, 'my name is___'. Here again we see tal- for the question and tel- for the answer.
Can you work out who we are talking about when we use this new -t ending? (Hint: it's not you, and it's not me).
lesson.designnote: Here the 'what is my/your name?' pattern is extended to show the important 's/he...' ending. At the same time, the full four-way system of [older/younger brother/sister] vs. the English two-way system of [brother/sister] is now laid out directly and completely. In the background here is also the use of word order to highlight relative importance of information: the repeated information is first, and then the key new information (the name asked for) comes right before the verb.

line.english: What is your older brother's name?
My older brother's name is Michael.
What is your older sister's name?
My older sister's name is Mary-Ann.
What is your younger brother's name?
My younger brother's name is John.
What is your younger sister's name?
My younger sister's name is Mary.

lesson.title: Identifying uncle, aunt, cousins
lesson.note: Let's learn some more words to talk about our families.
lesson.designnote: Three related kinship terms--- uncle, aunt, and cousin--- are introduced, plus a minimal introduction to 'many' and 'one'. Word order for informational importance/prominence is again demonstrated.

line.migmaq: Pugwelgig no'gmaq, gatu newte'jit teluisit Poligap.
line.english: I have lots of cousins [lit. 'many are my cousins'], but one is named Polycarpe.

lesson.title: Identifying grandparents
lesson.note: Let's practice discussing our family members.
lesson.designnote: Introducing grandparents, reinforcing earlier-introduced patterns.

lesson.title: Identifying deceased relatives
lesson.note: The ending -aq added here is mainly used to refer to the deceased. Sometimes you will also hear it used just for someone who has just gone away or even is just asleep (gone off to dreamland).

The -sn- and -pn- are both endings used to talk about the past. We will learn more about them later: for now, we can roughly say that the P-past is the main, plain, usual way of talking about the past.

The S-past has more special uses: in particular, it is what we usually use to ask questions about the past, like we do here. (You can try thinking about it as the "supposedly" past, since you usually use it when you don't have proof of what happened.
lesson.designnote: Based on previous lessons' kinship terms, we introduce the absentative (= deceased, no longer present) for people/animates: -aq. The P-past -p(n)- and the S-past -s(n)- both naturally come together with the absentative in this context. Not necessary to go into details on this for now with learners. But it is worth being prepared to explain that the P-past is used for a direct perspective on the past (the usual, "I saw it happen myself, or know it for sure"), and the S-past tends to be used for indirect perspective on the past, and in particular, for most questions about the past, as here.

lesson.title: Work/study
lesson.note: You now know enough that you can try to work out on your own the meanings of as many words as possible— by starting with the ones you already know.
One hint: who are we talking about when the same word has an -n on the end, and when it doesn't? It will help to think about 'what is your name' and 'my name is' phrases we've learned.
Another hint: etl- can be used to show the meaning 'doing', rather than 'did' or 'done'. It can also help emphasize that someone is in the process of doing something in a particular place.
Once you've worked out as much as you can on your own, try asking speakers and other learners for help, too!
lesson.designnote: Reviewing /tami (tett).../ 'where...' pattern, reviewing endings for 'me' and 'you', introducing 'work' and 'study/learn', and briefly, several other important patterns: mu ...-w 'I ... not ...', etl- 'be doing...'

line.english: I don't work, I'm a student [lit. 'I am studying/learning']

lesson.title: Speaking Native
lesson.note: Mi'gmaq is a language where speakers often draw on the knowledge that they share as members of the same (or a closely related) community. For this reason, some normal ways of talking in Mi'gmaq can seem not as specific as what English speakers are used to.

In Listuguj, for example, qame'g 'across (the river)' can often specifically mean Campbellton, and gm'tnigtug 'at the mountain' can often specifically mean the Sugarloaf. This way of talking is effective because speakers draw on their common understanding of where they are and which specific places would naturally tie to those words.

For the same reason, it is normal and in fact more natural in Mi'gmaq to say 'speak Native' when talking about speaking the Mi'gmaq language. More specific expressions are possible, but are usually only used when really needed, say, to talk about speaking different kinds of Native languages.
lesson.designnote: Introducing 'speak ___' verb in the form of 'speak Native'. Pointing out that 'speak Native' is the more common/natural way for Mi'gmaq speaks to convey what would usually be said in English as 'speak Mi'gmaq'. Also briefly introducing nige' 'now' and getu'- 'want to, going to', and the -nej 'let's...' patterns.

line.english: Do you speak Native [lit. 'speak Native', but used where English would say 'speak Mi'gmaw']
Do you want to speak Native now?

lesson.title: Afraid to speak Native
lesson.note: It can be a difficult thing to learn a language. Sometimes these fears keep learners from practicing because they are embarrassed. But in reality, most learners are feeling the same way.
lesson.designnote: Building on the preceding lesson, but now to address the most common problem faced by learners: embarrassment or fear of being laughed at. Also introduces 'everybody' and some basic terms for feelings; these will all be taught again in more detail in later lessons.

line.english: Do you want to speak Native now?
I'm afraid to speak Native, because I will be laughed at.
Everyone feels that way, at first.

unit.title: Seeing People and Things in Locations
unit.note: In this unit, you will learn how to talk about people and places. You will learn some more verbs and how to describe where people are.

lesson.title: Person Vocab
lesson.note: One cultural difference that may get lost in translation is related to the two words you just learned: gisigu and gisiguisgw. The English translation we give just says "old man" and "old woman", but in English both of those phrases may not seem as respectful as the Mi'gmaq words actually are.

In Mi'gmaq it isn't insulting to be called gisigu or gisiguisgw. These words indicate people who have fully matured and grown, who know as much as they are ever going to know. Somebody who is a gisigu or gisiguisgw is to be respected; it is not insulting to use those words (unless you are talking about somebody who is clearly not elderly).
lesson.designnote: Introduces a core set of animate nouns starting from people, going through primary gender + stage of life. This is more than just simple vocabulary. These words will be the anchors for demonstrating many other patterns in later lessons, which is one reason why they are kept to this bare but still useful minimum. It is also why the introduction of these words is slow and repetitive over this and the next two lessons, which give the plural, then the singular and plural together. The images for each noun are crucial to making the set easy to learn and remember. They are given together as a single row, and if possible, it would help to highlight each image as its sound is read through.

lesson.title: People Vocab
lesson.note: Let's learn to talk about one than one person at a time. Pay attention to the ending of each word, and try to remember how it is different than the word for the single person.

To talk about more than one of a person (rather than a thing), you add the ending -g. (Sometimes, the -g needs a vowel in front of it, making it -ug or -ig.) (When it comes after a -a or a -q, the ending is always -q, never -g.) And if the ending is added to -i or -u, those sounds come out as -i' and -u', as in gisigu'g.
lesson.designnote: Introducing the animal plural pattern through the plural forms of the preceding set of words. This may work best if the exact same pattern of introduction used for the singulars is repeated here, including the use of images described above.

lesson.title: Person and People Practice
lesson.note: Let's practice the difference between words for a person and words for people again.
lesson.designnote: This is the third of a three-part lesson set: here we repeat the singular and plural together to highlight and underline the singular vs. plural pattern. Using rows of images lined up together, singular on top of plural, is one way to reinforce this visually.

lesson.title: Thing Vocab
lesson.note: Here are some more words for household objects.
lesson.designnote: This lesson and the next two follow the same pattern as before, used to introduce the following words as the core set of inanimates, again as an anchor for many later lessons' material.

lesson.title: Things Vocab
lesson.note: Now let's learn their plurals.
lesson.designnote: Same pattern as used for animate plurals, for inanimate plurals.
lesson.explnote: To mark more than one of a thing (rather than a person), for most (but definitely not all) words the ending is -l. This comes out as -n if the word already ends in -n. This double -nn at the end of a word can be hard to hear at first, so it is a good idea to practice both saying it and listening for it. Like with people, if the ending is added to -i or -u, those sounds come out as -i' and -u', as in awti'l.

lesson.title: Thing and Things Practice
lesson.note: Let's practice plurals some more.
lesson.designnote: Same pattern as used for animate singular vs. plural pattern, now for inanimate singular vs. plural pattern.

lesson.title: I see [a person] in the road
lesson.note: In this lesson we learn two new things. The word nemi'g means 'I see him/her', and can be used with any of the words for people we have learned before. The ending -igtug marks a word as a place or location, just like English words like 'in', 'on', or 'at'.

Mi'gmaq has ways of showing those exact different kinds of places, but -igtug on the end of the word is usually enough. So for example, putting it on awti 'road' gets you 'in the road' or 'on the road'.
Now you can make complete full sentences on your own! Mix and match the words you know, using these patterns, and try them out with speakers!
lesson.designnote: This begins a series of lessons that use the key idea of 'see' to introduce the four-way pattern of 'see [{animate, inanimate} {singular, plural}]'. This lesson starts with nemi'g 'I see him/her [= animate singular]'; the later ones will work through the other three possibilities. This lesson also introduces the ending -igtug, added to mark a word as a location. Armed with these three basic components (noun, verb, location), the lesson (perhaps most importantly of all) shows learners that even this early on, they can already make their own full, complete, and real-world-useful sentences. This will be a theme in the course overall. For visuals, the original singular person images are put together with the "see" image.

line.english: I see an old man in the road.
I see a woman in the road.
I see a boy in the road.

lesson.title: I see [people] in the road
lesson.note: Starting from the word nemi'g 'I see him/her', we can expand to nemi'gig 'I see them'. You can use this word with any pair or group of people.

Notice that the endings sound very close to each other. This is a basic pattern of Mi'gmaq: words that are related to each other often share the same (or very similar) endings to show that relationship.
Now using the words for (groups of!) people, try to mix and match again with the words you know.
lesson.designnote: Continuing the lesson series using 'see' to introduce the four-way pattern of 'see [{animate, inanimate} {singular, plural}]': now doing so for animate plural by bringing the original plural people images together with the "see" image.

line.english: I see (some) old men in the road.
I see (some) women in the road.
I see (some) boys in the road.

lesson.title: I see [a thing] in the road
lesson.note: Before we learned the word nemi'g 'I see him/her', for talking about people. Now we learn the word nemitu 'I see it', for talking about things.
Again, this is the Mi'gmaq language showing how one word is related to another. In this case, showing that 'see' is related to 'it' (since 'it' is the thing that is 'seen').
Using the words for (single!) things you have learned, try to mix and match again to make new sentences like the ones in this lesson.
lesson.designnote: Continuing the lesson series using 'see' to introduce the four-way pattern of 'see [{animate, inanimate} {singular, plural}]': now doing so for inanimate singular by bringing the original singular thing images together with the "see" image.

line.english: I see a chair in the road.
I see a blanket in the road.
I see a rock in the road.

lesson.title: I see [things] in the road
lesson.note: From nemitu 'I see it', we can now expand to nemituann 'I see them [things]'. You can use this word for any pair or group of things. In fact, the extra -n on the end is the same ending you have seen in a'sunn 'blankets' and so on.
Once again, Mi'gmaq is giving each word matching endings to show how they are related to each other.
Again, using the words for (groups of) things you have learned, try to mix and match again to make new sentences like the ones in this lesson.
lesson.designnote: Continuing the lesson series using 'see' to introduce the four-way pattern of 'see [{animate, inanimate} {singular, plural}]': now doing so for inanimate plural by bringing the original plural thing images together with the "see" image.

line.english: I see (some) chairs in the road.
I see (some) blankets in the road.
I see (some) rocks in the road.

lesson.title: More Practice with Seeing
lesson.note: In this lesson, we are just going back over the four new words/patterns you have learned: nemi'g, nemi'gig, nemitu, and nemituann.
lesson.designnote: 4-way chart, demonstrating the 4-way contrast in review. Again, images and text are drawn directly from the above examples to make the review explicit and help learners confirm that their understanding is correct.

line.english: I see an old man in the road.
I see (some) old men in the road.
I see a chair in the road.
I see (some) chairs in the road.

lesson.title: Who is that woman standing at the rock?
lesson.note: Let's practice what we've learned so far with a short dialog!

line.migmaq: Ji'nm nemi'g, gaqamit awtigtug. Wen na?
line.english: I see a man, standing in the road. Who is that?
That's Joseph. He's my younger brother.

line.migmaq: Wen na ala e'pite's gaqamit gun'tewigtug?
line.english: Who is that young woman standing at the rock?
That's Mary-Ann. She is my younger sister.
Who is this man in the picture?
This is my older brother. His name is Michael.

unit.title: Numbers and Counting
unit.note: Now that we know some plurals, we can learn how to count. In this unit, you'll learn numbers and how to count people and objects.

lesson.title: How many people? 1-3, many.
lesson.designnote: This lesson introduces counting (of people), using only the minimum numbers/amounts (1, 2, 3, many) needed to show the basics of the system. Image files simply show these numbers: X number of countables together, either as a natural picture or a photoshopping of X number of identical images.
lesson.explnote: In this lesson, we learn to count people: asking how many, and giving answers.

lesson.title: How many things? 1-3, many.
lesson.note: In this lesson, we learn to count things: asking how many, and giving answers.
lesson.designnote: This lesson continues with the counting of things, again using only the minimum numbers/amounts (1, 2, 3, many) needed to show the basics of the system. Keeping the presentation identical to the preceding one should help confirm the pattern for learners. Image files again simply show these numbers: X number of countables together, either as a natural picture or a photoshopping of X number of identical images.

lesson.title: How many people do you see?
lesson.note: Now we'll start building more complex sentences.
lesson.designnote: This lesson combines the earlier nemi'g(ig)/nemitu(ann) pattern with the 'how many ___?' patterns just shown. As in earlier lessons, the main aim is helping learners see how they can now build more complex sentences. Image files again simply show these numbers: X number of countables together, either as a natural picture or a photoshopping of X number of identical images.

line.english: How many men do you see?
How many men do you see?
How many men do you see?
How many men do you see?

lesson.title: How many things do you see?
lesson.note: Remember how to talk about groups of things?
lesson.designnote: This lesson combines the earlier nemi'g(ig)/nemitu(ann) pattern with the 'how many ___?' patterns just learned, helping learners see how they can now build more complex sentences. Image files again simply show these numbers: X number of countables together, either as a natural picture or a photoshopping of X number of identical images.

line.english: How many chairs do you see?
I see one chairs in the road.
How many chairs do you see?
I see two chairs in the road.
How many chairs do you see?
I see three chairs in the road.
How many chairs do you see?

lesson.title: Counting to Ten
lesson.note: Here we'll learn how to count to ten.
lesson.designnote: A 10x10 chart of the numbers 1 to 100 is used here and in upcoming lessons, highlighting the number or numbers that match the sound recording. Keeping consistently to this single chart helps visually underline the patterns being learned.

lesson.title: Counting to One Hundred
lesson.note: Listen carefully to hear how the ending -sga'q gives you 10, 20, 30 and so on.
Notice that numbers 'six' through 'nine' can't combine directly with endings. Instead they use te's- after them as a stand-in. We will see this again and again in other patterns using numbers.
lesson.designnote: The 10x10 chart of the numbers 1 to 100 is used again, highlighting the number or numbers that match the sound recording. This is also the first less on to introduce pattern whereby [6, 7, 8, 9] usually cannot combine directly with a word/ending, and so use a following te's- as a stand-in.

lesson.title: Teens and up
lesson.note: The word jel basically means 'plus': so in Mi'gmaq, 'eleven' is really 'ten+one', 'twelve' is 'ten+two', and so on. It's the same again for 'twenty-one' and so on.
lesson.designnote: Demonstrating the use of "jel" in naming more complex numbers, we return to the 10x10 chart of the numbers 1 to 100, now highlighting the "in between" number/numbers that match the sound recording. Notice that these numbers are taught AFTER the [10, 20, 30...] progression.

lesson.title: Counting Hundreds
lesson.note: Counting hundreds is easy: you just put the numbers next to each other without worrying about special combination patterns.
lesson.designnote: Same highlighting system as above, with hundreds.

lesson.title: Counting Thousands
lesson.note: Counting thousands is the same as hundreds: you just put the numbers next to each other without worrying about special combination patterns.
lesson.designnote: Same highlighting system as above, with thousands.

lesson.title: How many people? 1-12
lesson.note: Here we go back to the patterns we learned for counting people, bringing in the higher numbers we have now learned.
Pay special attention to te's- again being used with 6, 7, 8, 9, and the usual use of jel. Notice also that the ending you learned on its own as -sga'q comes out here as -sgeg-.
lesson.designnote: This lesson combines the patterns of the original minimal 1, 2, 3, many people-counting system with the above higher number patterns to show learners how to count up to ninety-nine people.
For these higher numbers, it may be easier for the image to be simply the explicit numeral/math expressin "100 x" before a single image, and so on.

line.migmaq: Newtisgegsijig jel ta'pu. Newtisgegsijig jel ta'pu ji'nmug.

lesson.title: How many things? 1-12
lesson.note: Here we go back to the patterns we learned for counting things, bringing in the higher numbers we have now learned.

Pay special attention to te's-' again being used with 6, 7, 8, 9, and the usual use of jel. Notice also that the ending you learned on its own as -sga'q stays as -sga'q-, but will add the matching -l. The combination can also be said and written as -sqa'qal.
lesson.designnote: For these higher numbers, it may be easier for the image to be simply the explicit numeral/math expressin "100 x" before a single image, and so on.

line.migmaq: Newtisga'ql jel ta'pu. Newtisga'ql jel ta'pu mutputi'l.

lesson.title: How many people do you see? Large numbers
lesson.note: Let's practice counting some bigger groups of people.
lesson.designnote: Here we combine the 'see' patterns with the larger numbers for counting people (and similarly-treated words like 'star'). The larger numbers have been intentionally selected for easy visual/image presentation. Hence "25" as editing a single image of a child into a 5x5 configuration.

line.english: How many men do you see?
How many women do you see?
How many children do you see?
How many stars do you see?

line.migmaq: Nemi'gig lluigneg te'sisgegsijig jel na'n gloqowejg.

line.english: How many people do you see?

line.migmaq: Nemi'gig pesgunateg te'sisgegsijig jel pesgunateg mimajuinu'g.

lesson.title: How many things do you see? Large numbers
lesson.note: Now let's practice counting things.
lesson.designnote: Here we combine the 'see' patterns with the larger numbers for counting things. The larger numbers have been intentionally selected for easy visual/image presentation. Hence "36" as editing a single image of a rock into a 6x6 configuration.

line.english: How many chairs do you see?
How many chairs do you see?
How many chairs do you see?
How many chairs do you see?
How many chairs do you see?

lesson.title: How old are you?
lesson.note: In this lesson, as you learn how to say how old you are, notice one thing: the word you might expect for 'ten' has been replaced with an older one with the same meaning.
Keep an eye out for this older word: you will see it pop up in a few other places in Mi'gmaq.
lesson.designnote: Introducing another ta's- 'how many___?' pattern with -puna' 'be ___ years old' to show learners how to ask and give ages. Reinforces the 'me' and 'you' endings, as well as all the number patterns, including the older, now idiomatic element metla's- for 'ten'. Images use photos of people matching the age said: baby-toddler-kid-older kid-young adult-adult-older adult

lesson.title: How old is your mother?
lesson.note: Here is a short conversation we can have about ages. There are two important points to notice.
First, the word me' is used a lot in Mi'gmaq. Here it means 'still___'. You will see it later on also meaning 'more___, ___-er'.
Second, look at the last word, tapuisgegi-puna'p. When you replace the usual -t for 's/he' with -p, it changes the meaning from 'she IS twenty years old' to 'she WAS twenty years old'.
lesson.designnote: Same as above, but reviewing the -t ending for 's/he'. The final dialogue is just gives a few naturally related expressions as is, and brings another brief and simple introduction to the P-past endings.

line.english: Yes, they're still young. When I was born, my mother was twenty.

lesson.title: How old are you? (Conversation)
lesson.note: In this lesson we will again talk about two ideas: young, and old. Try to work out from the dialogue which words each mean which. Remember that their endings will tell you who is young, and who is old.
Once you have worked that out, you can see two common ways to say '(more)___ than___'. Both of them start with me', which here means 'more_, _-er'.
Then you can use either aq (which also you know as 'and') or jemu for the idea of 'than___'. So the patterns for 'more___ than___' are: -me'___ aq___ -me'___ jemu___
lesson.designnote: Taking the form of a single unbroken conversation, this lesson starts from the basic opposites gisigui- 'be old' and maljewejui- 'be young', and uses them to introduces two ways to say '(more)...than...': - me' ... aq ... - me' ... jemu ... It also introduces the related idea of 'so (much)...', expressed by te'uji- / tew'ji-. And also the very different sense of 'so, then ...' that the word na is used for.

line.english: My younger brother is ten. He's far younger than me.

line.migmaq: Na gi'l me' gisiguin jemu negm?

lesson.title: When were you born?
lesson.note: In this lesson, we see the S- and P-pasts again. And like before, the S-past is used here to ask a question, and the P-past is used to give a direct statement: the answer to that question.
So here we see -'s'p to ask a question about 'you' in the past. And then we see -ap to give the answer (or just make a statement) about 'me' in the past.
Pay close attention to the word ta'n. It has many uses; here we see it used to ask 'when___?' about the past.
lesson.designnote: Reviewing 'me' and 'you' past forms, through their natural conversational use around asking the month of someone's birth.

line.english: I was born in uh...May. And you?

lesson.title: Months
lesson.note: In this lesson you'll learn the names of all the months.

lesson.title: What's the date today?
lesson.note: In this lesson we learn the ending for what day of the month (what date it is) it is today. It should be easy to work out which word means 'today'; try to figure out also the words for 'first' and 'day'.
lesson.designnote: Introducing the -uguni-t ending for 'Xth date of the month', building again on number system. Also introducing amgwesewei 'first', na'gweg 'day', and especially, gisgug 'today'. An improved version might take the opportunity to introduce ugtejgewei 'last' in contrast to amgwesewei 'first', if it is in fact natural to say things like ugtejgewei na'gweg 'the last day'. For each, the image is a calendar with the actual date marked on it.

Later corrections suggested that "Gisgug amgwesewei na'gweg ula tepgunset." and "Gisgug amgwesewei na'gweg 'Ps'gewigu's." would be improved responses to the 1st question. May be worth recording and adding those in.

line.english: Today is the first day [of the month].
Today is the third day [of the month].
Today is the tenth day [of the month].
Today is the twenty-third day [of the month].
Today is the thirty-first day [of the month].

lesson.title: What date is your birthday?
lesson.note: Now that you know how to talk about your birthday and about specific dates, this conversation will show you how to put those together naturally.
Notice also the word gatu, which can mean 'but, however' but is also used to shift the topic of the conversation from one person/thing to another.
lesson.designnote: This is a simple review lesson, combining talking about birthdays with the naming of dates. In particular, it reworks the previous lesson's list-based material in the form of an actual simple conversation. It also brings to the front the use of gatu 'but, however; as for___' in its 'as for___' topic-shifting sense. Again use the exact calendar date pictures for each speaker.

line.english: What date do you have your birthday on?

line.migmaq: Ni'n aji-puna'i tapuisgegugunij jel si'st. Gatu gi'l?
line.english: I have my birthday on the 23rd. And you?
I have my birthday on the 11th.

lesson.title: When will your birthday be?
lesson.note: A few lessons back we saw ta'n used to ask "when?" about the past. Here we see ta'nug, which is used to ask "when?" about the future.

And yes, you guessed right: the endings for talking about "me" and "you" in the future are (for many speakers, at least) the same. The context of the conversation usually makes clear which one you mean, and you can always add in ni'n 'me' or gi'l 'you' if you need.
lesson.designnote: Again use the exact calendar date picture, with an arrow indicating ahead, or some other indicator of the future.

line.english: When will you have your birthday?
I'll have my birthday on the 9th of May.
When will you have your birthday?

line.migmaq: Ni'n aji-puna'tes metla'sugunij jel ne'w Gep't'gewigu's.
line.english: I'll have my birthday on the 14th of November.
When will you have your birthday?
I'll have my birthday on the 5th of August.

lesson.title: What time is it now?
lesson.note: Some hints for this lesson: -geget = 'almost', for something that will happen; -mejit = 'more', until something happens; -ga'l = 'quarter'.
Notice that end of the basic word ajiet changes a bit: in one case to match the word mu 'not yet/before', in another to show the future. Can you find both of these?
lesson.designnote: Introducing basic expressions for time. "Asugom ajiet" is specifically chosen as the main example to confirm that (at least for some speakers) that the placeholdern(/classifier?) te's- is not needed in this pattern. Learners are encouraged to start working out some of the new patterns involved on their own, but the focus remains on the key ajie- element. Images: show clock faces with the time.

line.english: It is almost/coming up on eleven o'clock.

line.migmaq: Mejit nangl minitl na newtisga'q ajietew jel newt.
line.english: Five more minutes, then it will be eleven o'clock [= 'five to eleven'].
A quarter (of an hour) more and it will be eight o'clock [='quarter to eight'].
It's a quarter before eight o'clock.
It's half past seven [lit. 'seven plus a half'].
It's a quarter after seven [lit. 'seven plus a quarter'].
I don't know. Have you lost your watch?

lesson.title: What time will it be?
lesson.note: In this lesson we will learn to ask about times in the future. Look for how the endings change for this meaning, and also especially for expressing '[at the time] when'.
lesson.designnote: This lesson focuses on using 'o'clock' expressions in the future: 'what time will it be?'. It introduces a number of future forms, but puts off explicit explanations for a future lessons: the goal here is to make those forms already somewhat familiar when the specific lesson on future endings is reached.

line.migmaq: Mnaq ugumuljin ajiegw. Mejit ga'l na ugumuljin ajietew.
line.english: It's not yet eight o'clock. A quarter (hour) more and then it will be eight o'clock.
What time will [it be when] we meet each other?
When it's six o'clock, that's when we'll meet each other.
What time will it be tomorrow [when] you go to work?

line.migmaq: Lluigneg ajietew jel aqatai natlugwei, wijei na te'si-gisg'g.
line.english: It'll be half past seven when I go to work, same as every day.

lesson.designnote: translation for "a'a, ni'n wijei" needs checking.

lesson.title: You finished Section 1!
lesson.note: Congratulations! You've worked hard. You've now learned enough to talk about yourself and your family, to ask questions, and to describe groups of people and things in different settings.

section.title: Animals, Food, Household
section.note: By now you know how to ask basic questions, how to describe yourself and your family, and how to count. You know some words for people and things and how to talk about different numbers of them.
In this section, we will build on those skills by learning vocabulary to do with animals, food, and other household objects. We'll practice describing people and things in different settings.

You've mastered some of the basics of the language by now. Keep up the good work, and keep practicing! Remember to listen to the audio files as many times as you need, and repeat the sentences until you feel confident with the sounds.

lesson.title: Meat
lesson.note: In English, we often use the same word for an animal, and the meat that comes from the animal. For instance, think of salmon (in the river) and salmon (with lemon juice). Sometimes, we also have unpredictable words, like "venison" meaning "deer meat".

In Mi'gmaq, there are different words for the animals and their meat,that follow a predictable rule. The rule goes like this: Simply add -ewei to the end of the animal's name, and that makes the word for the animal's meat. For example, lentug + -ewei = lentugowei "deer" + ("coming from" = "deer meat" "belonging to")
Sometimes, like above, the first vowel -ewei is pronounced in different ways, but they still mean the same thing!

Bonus info: you can use the same ending, ewei, with a pronoun or person's name if you want to make the possessive form of those words! It works a lot like the English 's. Mali + -ewei = Maliewei | ni'n + -ewei = ni'newei "Mary" + "belonging to" = "Mary's" | "me" + "belonging to" = "mine".

section.title: Motion, routines, sports
section.note: Now that you've gained a foundation in several conversation topics, we'll start focusing more on actions. Verbs are very important in Mi'gmaq: they contain a lot of information.

In this section, we'll talk about many of the activities you carry out in your daily life. We'll also learn some ways of talking to children. We'll learn words for parts of the body, and how to describe how you feel. We'll end by learning even more ways to ask about where people are going and what they are doing.
By now, you can carry out simple conversations with speakers. Try to find some other learners or speakers to practice with— it'll really help you improve!

unit.title: Child care, daily routine, house-care, and commands
unit.note: Now let's talk about some of the things we do every day.
A good way to practice this vocabulary is to narrate your actions to yourself (out loud or in your head) as you get ready in the morning.

lesson.title: Describing another person's routine
lesson.note: Now pretend that you are repeating someone else's description of their daily routine back to them.
lesson.designnote: Note slight variations in the responder's forms: she says egiljen instead of "egijjen". Both are common versions of 'read'. Similarly, "engosin" and "engopin" are both versions of "pemgopi".

line.english: Ah, every morning, you wake up.
You are lying in your bed.
After you get dressed, then you cook for yourself.

line.migmaq: Mijji; ilajin ugjit natlugwen. Aq natlugwen. Elien Listugujg. Na'te'l etllugwen.
line.english: You eat; you get ready to go to work. And you go to work. You go to Listuguj. There is where you work.
Then you arrive where you work.
When you get tired, then you rest.
Then you go back to work.
When you finish work, then you go home.
Then you arrive home [lit. 'at your (group's) house'].
When you have eaten, then you get sleepy.
When you wake up, then you go putter around in your garden.
You go back inside, then you sit down, and you read.

unit.title: Body parts, how they hurt, and possession
unit.note: In this unit, you'll learn the names for the parts of your body. You'll see how to talk about them if they are hurting. You'll also pick up on how possession works in Mi'gmaq.

lesson.title: My body parts
lesson.note: Here are the names for some of our body parts.
lesson.designnote: Words are given in singular, plural, or both, depending on how commonly each is used.

line.english: my lower leg my l ower legs
my big toe my big toes

lesson.title: My [body part] hurts. (animate)
lesson.note: Ouch! What hurts?

lesson.title: My [body parts] hurt. (animate)
lesson.note: Oh no! What else hurts?

lesson.title: My [body part] hurts. (inanimate)
lesson.note: More pain! Oh no! Where does it hurt?

lesson.title: My [body parts] hurt. (inanimate)
lesson.note: Here's some more practice describing body pains.

lesson.title: Mine, Yours, and His or Hers
lesson.note: What's yours and what's mine?
You probably already know how to say 'my___' and 'your___' in Mi'gmaq: you just add the first letter of ni'n 'me' or of gi'l 'you', that is, just n- and g-.
As you'll see in our second set of words, though, when words start with a vowel a /-t-/ sound usually is added to link everything together.

Only a few words that are either parts of the body (like your teeth) or parts of your family (like your father) do not need this /-t-/ added in before a vowel. A word starting in consonants just adds the n- and g- right before it, nothing else.

But you will notice that when the combination of n- or g- with the following consonant needs some help to make it pronounceable, a /'/ sound comes in to make it easier to say. When this happens, you'll notice that the 'n- sound in particular sounds sort of "stopped", almost like "nt" at the end of a word in English.
lesson.designnote: Good to follow body parts, as reinforcing possession morphosyntax. This lesson introduces the three basic patterns of possession marking (n-V-, 'nt-V-, and n-C-). It starts with the rarest case: the n-V- pattern of nujj 'my father' rather than the broadest case ('n-C-) for two reasons. First is that nujj 'my father' and similar family relationship terms are ones learners are likely to already be somewhat familiar with. Second is that they are somewhat exceptional, and introducing the exceptions before the broad pattern helps prevent learners from overusing the broad pattern.

lesson.title: The -m mystery
lesson.note: If you know the word a'su'n 'blanket', you might be wondering why this -m is added when it is possessed.

There is a simple reason for this, which goes back to how precise the Mi'gmaq language tends to be about different kinds of relations. Words for parts of the body (like your teeth) or parts of your family (like your father) are naturally related to you. But most other things in the world are not.
Mi'gmaq allows you to set up any old word as related to you (or me) by adding -m to it. From there, you can then just add on the n- or g- and so forth as usual.

This is not a 100% rule. A few body parts and family members actually do use -m, and a few things that aren't actually don't use the -m. But by and large, when in doubt, if you use the -m, you will be correct, and at worst, just a little over-correct, and fluent speakers will easily set you straight.

lesson.title: Understanding the 'his/her' sound
lesson.note: For 'his' and 'her', the added sound is usually w-.
However, if the w- comes before a consonant, it is pronounced (and spelled) ug-.
Try saying wpaqam (especially with that noticeable "stopped" sound) and you'll see how ugpaqam is a much easier and more natural way to get the sound across.

lesson.title: Understanding the 'his/her' mystery, part 1
lesson.note: So what about 'his/her father'? Well, we held off on this for a two reasons.
First is that /w/ and /u/ are basically two versions of the same sound in Mi'gmaq, which makes /w-/ drop out completely before /u/. The w- can sometimes change /g/ to /gw/ as well.
Second is, as you may have noticed, this -l on the end. It sounds exactly the same as the plural for things, but because it's used on people, it has a completely different meaning.
When you hear the -l on the end of a word naming a person, it tells us two things.
First, that there is some main person we are thinking of first, as our starting point.
Second is that we start from that main person to get to the person with the '-l' on them. It shows that the person we are talking about it related to the main person in some way.

lesson.title: Understanding the 'his/her' mystery, part 2
lesson.note: Here's an example to walk through slowly.

Whenever we say 'her father', we must be thinking of whoever 'she/her' is first, in order to talk about the father. If we say 'his mother', we must be thinking of whoever "he/his" is first, in order to talk about the mother.

(This is why we will always hear the -l on person words if they have a 'his/her', since that always means we're not going directly to the person, but instead starting from/through whoever that 'his/her' is talking about.)

Since there is nothing like this in English, this may take some getting used to. But as you go along, you will find that it is actually a very simple idea (and in the end, you may wonder why English doesn't have it).
For now, it will be enough to recognize that the -l on a person word tells you that we are viewing them by way of someone else who is, for the moment, first in our minds.

Another way to learn it is just to memorize simple patterns like the ones below just by ear. Then the -l will come in naturally when it is needed without having to think through why it's there: it will just sound right.

unit.title: Motion and position
unit.note: This unit focuses on motion and position. You'll learn how to ask where people are and how to describe your position.
You'll learn some new verbs to describe what people are doing, too.

lesson.title: Where are you?
lesson.note: In this lesson, we'll practice asking where people are, and describing our location.

line.migmaq: E'e. Gi'l gujmug mu eimu'n, aq ni'n mu eimu lamuguomg.
line.english: Yes. You're not outside, and I'm not inside.

lesson.title: Where is she?
lesson.note: Now we'll ask where other people are and talk about their locations.

line.english: Yes, she's in the other room.

lesson.title: Where is everyone else?
lesson.note: You're very curious today and want to know where everyone is. Here's how to ask about them.

lesson.title: Is your mom here?
lesson.note: We'll practice asking about locations some more.

line.english: No, she's not here/present. She's outside.

lesson.title: Position Verbs
lesson.note: Some verbs tell us what position people are in, whether they are standing, sitting, or lying down. We'll practice describe people's positions in this lesson.

line.migmaq: Ge' lapa'si! Ala' ji'nm gaqamit awtigtug.
line.english: Look over there! Over there there's a man standing in the road.

line.migmaq: Ge' lapa'si! Ala' gajuewj pemgopit miti'sigtug.
line.english: Look over there! Over there there's a cat sitting(!!!?) in a tree.
Look over there! There's a dog lying on the grass.
Why do you want me to look at everything?
And your brother's sitting around inside.
And the cat is lying around in the next room.
I know that of him. That cat is always lying around.

lesson.title: Where are you going?
lesson.note: Let's practice asking where people are doing.

line.english: I'm going to Campbellton (lit. 'across the river').
I'm going across. [the usual way to say 'go to Campbellton']

line.migmaq: Mu tami eliew. Pas'g aleii tett.
line.english: I'm not going anywhere. I'm just hanging around here.

lesson.title: Who's that wandering around?
lesson.note: Here's some more practice asking questions about where people are and what they're doing.

line.english: Who is that wandering around in the road?

line.migmaq: 'Njignam na. Te'si-gisg'g pas'g ala'si Listugujg, gatu negm ma' tam-se'g 'liegw.
line.english: That's my little brother. Every day he just wanders around in Listuguj, but he won't go anywhere else.
Who is that coming this way?
It's a bear. Let's get out of here [lit. 'Let's run away']!

line.migmaq: Lentug na. Mutt me'tew, jijuaqa ugsmugwatew.
line.english: It's a deer. Don't make a sound, or else it will run away.

line.migmaq: Tia'm na. Mutt gigja'siw ta'n eig.
line.english: It's a moose. Don't go close to where it is.
I'm going to Campbellton. I'm going shopping.
Where did you go/where have you come from?
I went to Campbellton. I went (am back from) shopping.

lesson.title: Two people are going
lesson.note: In Mi'gmaq, remember, we use different words for different 'you's and 'we's. We'll practice them in this lesson.
In this lesson, pretend that there are two people doing things together and another person asking them what they have planned.

line.english: We (2) are going to Campbellton. We (2) are going shopping.
We (2) are going to Campbellton. We (2) are going shopping.
I don't know about you guys. Where do you (2) want to go?

lesson.title: Two people are coming back
lesson.note: Let's get some more practice with 'you' and 'we'. We'll pretend the two came back.

line.english: We (2) went to Campbellton. We (2) went (are back from) shopping.

line.migmaq: Qame'g eta weja'ti'gw. Apanguai'gw. Mu migwite'tmu'n?
line.english: We (me+you) went to Campbellton. We (me+you) went (are back from) shopping. Don't you remember?
Where did we (2, not you) go?

line.migmaq: Mu geju'luoq. Ge' gilew tlimigw ta'n weja'tioq!
line.english: I don't know about you guys. You guys tell me where you (2) went!

lesson.title: Even more are going
lesson.note: Now pretend there is a whole group of people we are talking about.

line.english: We (group) are going to Campbellton. We (group) are going shopping.
We (group) are going to Campbellton. We (group) are going shopping. You didn't know?

line.migmaq: Mu geju'luoq. Ge' gilew tlimigw ta'n el'taioq.
line.english: I don't know about you guys. You guys tell me where you (group) are going!

lesson.title: Even more are coming back
lesson.note: Let's get more practice, pretending that the group has returned.

line.english: We (group) went to Campbellton. We (group) went (are back from) shopping.

line.migmaq: Qame'g eta weitaigw. Apangua'ti'gw. Mu migwite'tmu'n?
line.english: We (group) went to Campbellton. We (group) went (are back from) shopping. Don't you remember?

line.migmaq: Mu geju'luoq. Ge' gilew tlimigw ta'n weita'ioq.
line.english: I don't know about you guys. You guys tell me where you (group) went!

lesson.title: Have you ever been to Gesgapegiaq?
lesson.note: In this lesson, we'll ask and answer questions about whether we've ever done certain things.

line.english: Have you ever been to Listuguj?

line.migmaq: E'e, gi's wejiei. Na'te'l eta tleiawi!
line.english: Yes, I've been there before. That's where I'm from, after all!
Have you ever been to Campbellton?
Yes, but I haven't been there in a long time.
Have you ever been to Qospem (the lake)?
Have you ever been to Sipug (the river)?
Have you ever been to Jake's camp?
Have you ever been to Red Bank?

line.migmaq: E'e, aq elg gi's wejiei Natuaqaneg.
line.english: Yes, and I've also been to Eel Ground.
Have you ever been to Gesgapegiaq?

line.migmaq: Moqwa', mnaq wejiew ni'n Gesgapegiaq, gatu gi's wejiei Glaqatigejg.
line.english: No, I haven't been to Gesgapegiaq, but I have been to Carleton before.
Have you ever been to Montreal?

line.migmaq: Moqwa', mnaq wejiew Muliang, pas'g we'gwa'siap Gepeg.
line.english: No, I haven't been to Montreal; I've only gotten as far as Quebec City.
Have you ever been to Big Cove and Burnt Church?

line.migmaq: E'e, gi's wejieiann. Gatu sa'q giaspiwjiei 'Sgno'patijg.
line.english: Yes, I've been to them. But it's been a long time since I went to 'Sgno'patijg.
Have you ever been to the Gasp?
How wouldn't I? My daughter used to live there.

line.migmaq: Gi's gi'l wejien Epegwitg gisna Unama'gig?
line.english: Have you ever been to Prince Edward Island or Nova Scotia?
Yes, I've been to them both.
Have you ever been to Eskasoni?
Yes, I've been there before; I went with Theresa.
Have you ever been to Shubenacadie?

line.migmaq: E'e, gi's wejiei. Newtejgeg el'ta'ieg'p naji-tu'a'tieg'p na'te'l .
line.english: Yes, I have been there before. Once we went to go play ball there.
Have you ever been to Dead Man's Lake?
Yes, I've been there before. It's been a good long time.

lesson.title: Did you just come from the woods?
lesson.note: Here's a diaog to practice what we've been learning to far.

line.english: Did you just come from the woods?
Did you just come from the shore?
Yes, I went (am back from) swimming.
Did they (group) just arrive from Montreal?
Yes, they have just told me (let me know).
Didn't you see the moose running along in the road?
No, I have just come outside.
Did you just come from the mountain?
Yes, I have just come down(hill).
I have just washed my hands!

lesson.title: Let's go to the lake!
lesson.note: Here's a final conversation to practice. You've learned so much in this section— well done!
lesson.designnote: At some point discuss 'swimming to play around' vs. 'swimming to go somewhere specific'.

line.english: To the lake! Let's go swimming!
Let's go to the store first...I want to go buy some sweets.

section.title: Advanced Verbing
section.note: You've learned a lot so far! In this lesson, we'll get comfortable with some more advanced verbs.

unit.title: Wants and Needs, Again
unit.note: In this unit, we'll learn how to talk about what we want to do and what we need to do. These are important skills for communicating more complicated ideas than we've learned so far.

lesson.title: Have to
lesson.note: In English, we use extra verbs to say these things. For instance, we combine "need to" with another verb to mean that we need to do that verb.
In Mi'gmaq, we add amuj pa before the verb.

line.english: I have to take care of my child.

lesson.title: Have to practice
lesson.note: Let's practice 'have to' some more with some short dialogs.

line.migmaq: E'e, natlugwei. Mu getu'-natlugwew, gatu amuj pa natlugwei.
line.english: Yes, I'm going to work. I don't want to go to work, but I have to go to work.
Yep,I'm back from work. I'm so tired!

line.migmaq: E'e, etllugwei. Te'si-gisg'g na ne'w ajiet gaqlugwei, gatu gisgug na'n ajietew.
line.english: Yes, I'm working. Every day I finish working at four o'clock, but today it will be five o'clock.

line.migmaq: Ni'n mu amuj pa na elugwew gisgug. Nmu'lt's to'q na'n ajiej.
line.english: Me, I don't have to work today. I'll see you then when it's five.

lesson.title: Want to
lesson.note: Now let's learn how to say 'want to'. Depending on the context where you say it, the word getu' can mean either 'going to do' or 'want to do'.
In these dialogues, we'll be using contexts that suggest getu' = 'want to do', and some other contexts that suggest getu' = 'going to do'. Keep your eye out for which translation goes where!

line.english: Do you want to come with me?
I'm going across [to Campbellton]. I want to get some U.S. money.
Yes, I will go with you, but first I want to hang out the laundry.
I think it's going to rain.
Oh, then for now I won't hang out the laundry.
So will you want to eat there?
Yes. Because I don't want to cook today.

lesson.title: Want to practice
lesson.note: This dialogue shows a couple words that have getu' built right into them! Can you figure out why getu' might always be a part of those words?
lesson.designnote: These highlight the few words that idiomatically have getu'- built into them, both to help students see the connection and not be confused by it.

line.english: You're sleepy. Go, go to bed.
Go, go have a drink, then you'll go lie down right away!

unit.title: Tense
unit.note: In this unit, we'll how to talk about when events happened, whether they've happened, or whether they're going to happen.

lesson.title: I've done
lesson.note: Let's learn how to talk about things we've done.

The expression gi's or gisi is another word like getu' that can change its meaning a little depending on context. This dialog shows that gi's/gisi can mean 'have done' OR 'can do/be able to do', just by changing what it is you're talking about.
lesson.designnote: Should have explicit note that this can mean either 'have done' or 'can do, be able to do', depending on context.

line.migmaq: Gi's ta's'g gisa'tu. Gatu mu gis-gaqa'tu.
line.english: I have done some of it. But I can't finish it.

line.migmaq: Muta mu gisgitmu ta'n goqwei ula 'gtuteminu gisui'g'g.
line.english: Because I can't read what this (non-Native) friend of ours has written.
I will be able to help you, so that you can finish it.

lesson.title: We (inclusive) vs. We (exclusive)
lesson.note: In English, 'we' can mean you and me, you and me plus some other people, or me and some other people, but not you.
In Mi'gmaq, though, there are different ways of saying 'we' including you and 'we' not including you.
lesson.designnote: Recording this properly requires at least two female, two male voices; two older and two younger: possibly JV+MAM, VM+JM, and JW+RM]

line.english: We are old; while you (one person) are young.
We are women; while you are a man.
We are men; while you are a woman.

line.migmaq: Ginu gisigui'gw: gi'l gisiguin, aq ni'n elg gisigui.
line.english: We are old: you are old, and I too am old.

line.migmaq: Ginu maljewejui'gw: gi'l maljewejuin, aq ni'n elg maljewejui.
line.english: We are young: you are young, and I too am young.

line.migmaq: Ginu e'pitewi'gw: gi'l e'pitewin, aq ni'n elg e'pitewi.
line.english: We are women: you are a woman, and I too am a woman.

line.migmaq: Ginu ji'nmui'gw: gi'l ji'nmuin, aq ni'n elg ji'nmui.
line.english: We are men: you are a man, and I too am a man.

lesson.title: Weather and tense
lesson.note: In this lesson, we'll learn how to talk about the weather in the past, present, and future. Taking the present tense as the default, the past and future show up as different endings on the verb.
In general, past = -p and future = -tew (sometimes, you see other letters hanging on to these ones to make them easier to pronouce).

For example, to talk about rainy weather yesterday, you say:ulagu, gigpesaqap: yesterday, it rained; today, you say:gisgug, gigpesaq: today, it's raining; tomorrow, you say:sapo'nug, gigpesatew: tomorrow, it will rain.

One more thing about the future tense: in addition to adding -tew at the end of the verb, the future tense can also change the beginning of the word. It happens when the FIRST vowel of the present tense form is an e, and the change basically just removes the e in the future tense. Then to make it easier to say, a ' is often added to the start of the word.
You'll get the hang of this the more you speak the language; for now, just learn these forms and watch out for the "remove e" rule in the future.
lesson.designnote: Already added into CAN8. May want to add 'it is/was/will be hot', to match the 'cold' series

line.english: There was lightning and (there was) thunder.
There is lightning and (there is) thunder.
There will be lightning and (there will be) thunder.
It was windy, the wind was blowing.
It is windy, the wind is blowing.
It will be windy, the wind will blow.

lesson.title: Give me an apple!
lesson.note: Let's practice asking for food.

line.designnote: or: Muta getu'tm 'because I'm hungry for it'

line.migmaq: Amuj gewisinn: tmg gelutmn wen'ju'su'n, toqo nige' jagej pewalt.
line.english: You must be hungry: first you ask for an apple, then now you want a lobster.

line.migmaq: Newte'jinnitl pas'g? Amujpa ignmajig tapusinnijig. Tepiaq tel-guwising, 'tqopata.
line.english: Just one? You should give her two. She's hungry enough, she'll eat both of them.
So be it: I will give her two.

lesson.title: I give you an egg
lesson.note: Let's practice talking about giving people things.

line.migmaq: Muta te'si-gisgug, wa'w ignmul. Toqo-jiw pas'g newte' wen'ju'su'n ignumuin. Mu tepianug.
line.english: Every day, I give you an egg. And then you only give me an apple. It's not enough.

line.migmaq: Na to'q, nige' tapu'gl wen'ju'su'nn ignmulann. Tepiatew?
line.english: Okay, now I'm giving you two apples. Will it be enough?

line.migmaq: Tapu'gl wen'ju'su'nn ignmuinn? Ugjit newte' wa'w? Me' mu tepianug.
line.english: You're giving me two apples? For one egg? It's still not enough.

line.migmaq: Na to'q, nige' tapusijig tap'tang elt ignmulanig. Tepiatew nige'?
line.english: Okay, now I'm giving you two potatoes, too. Will it be enough now?

line.migmaq: Tapusijig tap'tang ignmuinig? Aq elt tapu'gl wen'ju'su'nn? Ugjit newte' wa'w? Tepiatew na nugu'!
line.english: You're giving me two potatoes? And also two apples? For one egg? Oh all right, that will be enough.
Every day, I give my older brother one lobster.
And he gives me one eel.

line.migmaq: Aq te'si-gisgug, tapusinnijig atugwa'su'g ignmaqi nmis.
line.english: And every day, I give my older sister two trout.
And she gives me two tomatoes.

line.migmaq: Aq te'si-gisgug, nsis ignmuatl nmisnenn negla jagejl.
line.english: And every day, my older brother gives our older sister that lobster.

line.migmaq: Aq nmis ignmuaji nsisinenn negla atugwa'su'g.
line.english: And our my older sister gives our older brother those trout.

lesson.title: Let me give you socks!
lesson.note: Here's some more practice with tense.
lesson.designnote: phonological highlighting of easy-to-miss contrast between -n and -nn

line.migmaq: Gisgug aji-puna'n! Ge' to'q ignmulapnn signn!
line.english: Today you're having your birthday! Let me give you socks!

line.migmaq: Ignmuin sign? Goqwei ugjit? Ma' ulapetmu newte' sign.
line.english: You're giving me a sock? What for? I won't get good use out of one sock.
I said, "I'm giving you socks"! Socks, not sock.

line.migmaq: A', ignmuinn signn. Nestasi nige'. Wela'lin! Muta gewtaqsigi.
line.english: Oh, you're giving me socks. I understand now. Thanks! Since my feet are cold (I feel cold in my feet/have cold feet).
Every time I have a birthday, my big sister gives me socks.
A sock? You won't get good use out of one sock.

line.migmaq: Teluap, "Ignmuitl signn"! Signn ignmuitl, mu sign.
line.english: I said, "She gives me socks"! Socks she gives me, not (a) sock.
Oh, I understand. You've done well: I don't have any socks.
And every time I have a birthday, my older brother gives me potatoes.

line.migmaq: E'e. Tap'tang ignmuiji. Muta apjiw al'guwisin.
line.english: Yes. He gives me potatoes. Because I'm always going around hungry.

unit.title: Daily conversation
unit.note: You've learned how to have a lot of conversations! In this unit, we'll learn even more helpful conversation phrases.

lesson.title: Warnings and Requests
lesson.note: So far, we've mostly practiced questions and answers. In this lesson, we'll learn how to give warnings and ask people to do things.

line.english: Put it down, let it go.

lesson.title: Requests for children
lesson.note: Here are some helpful commands and requests for when you are taking care fo children.

line.english: Leave h/her alone, stop bothering h/her!
Stop running around, I have a headache.

lesson.note: This lesson is meant to help you practice conversation you might use around children. It's a dialog about getting ready in the morning.

line.english: Get up! You have to go to school.
Hurry up, you'll miss your bus.

lesson.title: Using bathroom, taking baths, brushing teeth
lesson.note: Let's continue the previous lesson by learning bathroom phrases.

line.english: It's just the right temperature warm.
Get into the water [= the tub].
Get into the water and wash yourself.
Put the cap back on (the toothpaste).

lesson.note: Here are phrases to do with getting dressed and getting ready in the morning, particularly if you are talking to children.

line.english: Which shirt do you want to wear?
Where are your socks? Go get them.
Button up your shirt.[same as above].

unit.title: Bonus dialog
unit.note: You're almost done with this section. You've learned so much! Here is a short review unit to help you remember and practice everything you've learned.

lesson.title: Did you have pets?
lesson.note: This lesson features a dialogue between a man and a woman. Their voices might be slightly hard for you to understand, but don't worry about getting every word. Being able to pick things up from a conversation that is full of things you haven't studied yet is an important part of learning a new language.

line.english: Did you have pets when you were young?

line.migmaq: E'e, 'nsis aq ni'n eggunget'p'ni'g gitg: gajuewj aq nmuj.
line.english: Yes, my older brother and I, we both had them. a cat and a dog.
Do you remember what they were named/called?
I remember the (late) cat was called "Jugi'pi" ("Come run to me.") and the (late) dog was called "Wigum" ("Call him here/invite him. Imperative").
What breed of pets were your pets?

line.migmaq: Gajuewjaq na poqtaqai-m'qtawe'g aq nmujaq na wisaqamugsit. Gatu getu'-witm amgwesewei nmujaq nenaqapna 'ntlamugsis ugtueml teluisipnaq "Gilu".
line.english: The cat was completely black and the dog is golden-coloured. But I want to mention first dog that I knew was my uncle's dog, his name was "Gilu".
